Speaking of light and energy waves I saw the episode on using thermal imagery apps on a phone, have you done episodes on the near-infrared? I work in Lidar and am suuuper fascinated and love talking about all things remote sensing. And I LOVE teaching. I work for a company that does LiDAR, bathymetry, thermal, hyperspectral and aerial imagery. There are a few other things we can do, too, but those are our main specialties. I'd love to tell you more as remote sensing is so helpful. The projects I typically on are for utility companies. We can tell them of the specific 4,367 trees that are within a danger zone distance of power lines after we collect the LiDAR, clean it up, classify everything and factor in specific dimensions and the swing and sag of power lines. It's cool stuff!

talking about internet speed, there is latency and there is bandwidth. one can have the ability to download large files fast and still have a slow acting internet.
latency refers to how fast your postcard reaches it's destination; bandwidth refers to how big (or how many) of a postcard can the carrier transport from one point to another over a given time... for small traffic, such as emails, chat, VoIP, browsing, etc, latency is more important that bandwidth.



search for "ping". a useful way to check how quickly a server (such as youtube, google, etc) responds to your requests. it can vary from 5ms all the way up to seconds... anything below 30ms is considered good response time (except for locally connected devices where the latency should be below 10ms).

There's been some models proposed recently that suggest that satellites could beam laser transmissions faster than the fiber optic cable system because they are transmitting through the vacuum of space. And that's actually one of the less interesting things going on right now. Perhaps satellites and the NewSpace tech going up into low Earth orbit could be a future topic for a show?

The real bottleneck in fiber optic communications isn't transmission speed but server speed and volume of traffic. I've seen it take 20 to 30 minutes for an email to get from one computer to another computer in the same room.
Very interesting!

It would take a bit longer because you're uploading your email to your mail server. It will then be put into queue along with other people's email. When it time for your mail turn, it will then be sent to the destination's mail server. But first it need to find out where the destination mail server is. It has to hit the DNS server of the recipient domain. Once found, then it will send it to that mail server.
Then the recipient mail client will have to check the server for new mail every certain interval. Once it sees a new email, then it'll be downloading it for viewing.
As long as the mail and DNS server are working, it will be done in less than 5min. Still faster than snail mail.

I appreciate you attempting to shed light on such a complex communication paradigm, but it's far more complicated than you've let on here. For one thing, fibre-to-the-home is not at all common. Most fibre-optic lines in North America, for example, branch off to COs that propagate aDSL copper lines to the home with radically different upload- and download speeds. That 1 ms latency for glass fibre can easily turn into 15 ms of latency over a slow aDSL connection after it's fed over a Wifi AP in the residence.

If you follow the discourse then, it should be clear why NSA and CIA assurances that they do not monitor domestic communications is hollow. The routes taken by message packets can remain domestic or they can travel internationally. Once message packets leave the US they're fair game for spy agencies. Think about that the next time you send a 'private picture' via e-mail. People at NSA could be sharing it amongst themselves.
Sometimes I think about the complexities of the Internet when texting someone who is physically near me.

Okay. Wait. If you are going to discuss how the internet works and owl post, the following Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF, who are the standards organization behind the technologies used for the internet) RFCs (Request For Comments, the way the IETF publishes the standards it makes) need to be mentioned:

A Standard for the Transmission of IP Datagrams on Avian Carriers:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1149

IP over Avian Carriers with Quality of Service:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2549

Adaptation of RFC 1149 for IPv6:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6214

So actually, the IETF has protocols for sending internet packets by bird.

Yes, they may be April fool's jokes but they have actually seen use, and hilariously, data transfer by pigeon can be faster than internet connections in some places:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_over_Avian_Carriers

In high school, I won the 1975 state science fair and was flown to New York (from Amite, La.) by the military (their prize) with my physics teacher for a tour of Bell Labs (where I hoped to work in laser communication techniques after getting a degree in physics) and to give a demo of my science project "LASER AUDIO-VIDEO HOLOGRAPHY: TELEVISION OF THE FUTURE" One physics student from each state was sent. Of course there were no cell phones, internet, email, not really anybody even had computers then! I did get my physics degree, but my interest shifted to holography--almost exclusively! I now work with computer-generated holography (CGH) and anaglyphs (published in "Circuit Cellar" mag.)
ANYWAY, I was fascinated by your water light guide, and would like to suggest trying it with a stream of water in "LAMINAR FLOW". This is a super smooth water stream that actually looks like it is a tube of perfectly clear solid glass!! I just saw this and your video today. The construction of the laminar flow nozzle is on youtube. Title: "MAKING A LAMINAR FLOW NOZZLE" at
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o5L6W0YoAd4 I hope to build one and find a way to place a small laser diode inside--maybe full color (RGB). I guess even a 3W LED star (see EBAY) should work! Nikola Tesla invented such a water flow fountain 100 years ago--Now with all the new stuff that has emerged since, that resonance patent should be a cinch! The title of the patent is simply "FOUNTAIN" which was really designed to employ resonance (like most of his MANY patents). Good luck with all your outstanding videos--there is really 'something' unique about them!

Show this video to flattards. Flattards cannot grasp the concept of light bending over the horizon due to humidity! They're pathetic. See, the earth's ionosphere may be way up there, but it's effects run all the way to the very core. It ionizes water just a bit along a the plane wrapping earth, so water connects along this plane is positive ions which induct light. Most people don't know this but the first inter-continental ballistic missile test had a big problem. Gravity beyond the ionosphere was suddenly lost much more than they had assumed, so the missile was in space a few more seconds than anticipated before rounding the horizon to communicate with the next station. We didn't share this information with Russia and laughed when they had to find it out themselves (haha did it first!). So if you can do this here, and space contains so much h and o, consider what galaxies are doing with light and what you aren't seeing.

Something you might not have considered: With how the internet is structured, it is possible that some packets never arrive or arrive multiple times.
They could also come in different orders.

That's why packets contain information about which part of the message they contain, so the message can be reassembled. In case a packet doesn't arrive, the sender will simply send it again. The receiver has to send back a "got it" message. Otherwise known as ACK. ("acknowledgement")

Packets could also become corrupted on the way. It's not impossible to imagine that something could happen to the data underway. Part of the packet is therefore a checksum so you can make sure your data is intact.
This is actually a lot less common with fiber optics, but long copper cables are quite a problem in this regard. :)

(Note: For simplicity I'm assuming TCP packets)

9:05 Not anymore. At least not in the ocean (they used to get broken relatively often and repairing them was difficult). Nowadays we dope the optical fiber with certain elements (like erbium) which absorb light of certain wavelengths (which forces their valence electrons into higher orbitals) and amplify light of other wavelength (when disturbed by a photon of the right wavelength, a valence electron will drop to a lower orbital and emit a second photon identical to the original one). Basically, in addition to the data, you fire a second laser into the optical fiber and the entire cable becomes one giant amplifier. Much more reliable and faster (and cheaper for long cables) than repeaters.

sending packets across the ocean is fast because they aren't being asynchronous packets at that point; they're packaged into 'frames' in a synchronous connection and there aren't frequent stops to have their address checked and to be routed differently.  The fibres are the fast part; it's the computers/servers in-between that add latency

if you drill a hole in the bottlecap and put a longer straw in it, you can get a constant flow rate according to Bernoulli's principle. Use glue or blu tack for seal between the cap and the straw. You can adjust the flowrate by changing the lenght of the straw. So you just get the perfect constant laminar speed and the experiment will last longer.

Fiber optic is certainly impressive but, given advances in quantum teleportation (another really cool topic), I'm not so sure that it's the technology of the future for data transmission.

Our desire to download does cause us to have higher download than upload speed, but somewhat indirectly. ISPs have border contracts with each other  which penalize one side or the other for asymmetric communication. Many ISPs address the effective asymmetry by hosting datacenters (frequently through more peering contracts). They provision assuming folks want more download speed  (which is generally true), but that in turn incentivizes  them to penalize folks who rock the boat, both because of provisioning costs and because if the average home use were symmetric, a fraction of their business model would dry up.
🙍 that wasn't "Happy Physicsing!" at the end !

If your connection is ADSL then part of the reason that the download speed is higher than the upload is crosstalk. For You->Exchange the signal is at its weakest at the exchange where there are lots of other lines also coming in, so it's the hardest to get a clear signal. So, the frequency bands that suffer least from crosstalk are used, but that's quite a narrow range of the total.

For the other direction the signal/wire is coming in to your home at its weakest 1-10m or more from the nearest other line, and thus there's less issue with crosstalk. That means they can use a wider range of frequencies for that. And of course this s all constrained by the range of frequencies that work down a (hopefully!) copper (not aluminIum!) cable.

So, with ADSL they could try to even up the speeds, but gaining X B/s of upload will cost more than that off the download (as they'll have to use a wider spread for the channel to try and overcome the crosstalk issue).

And, yeah, historically most people only need enough upload to cover things like the TCP ACK/replies side of whatever they're downloading/streaming.

Fibre To The Premises should be immune the issue. Depending on range Fibre To The Cabinet could still have the issue (it's still VDSL from the cabinet to/from the premises). Even with my awesome line very close to the cabinets I'm on an 80/20Mbps package. The sync started around 95/25Mbps and has settled down to 93672/28273 kbit/s.

And yet, you haven't looked at the different type of fiber optics !

As someone else commented - Even more interesting than sending light down the fiber, we send MULTIPLE "colors" or wavelengths of light down fiber: Multimode. With the use of a fiber optic multiplexer, we can do what's called Wavelength-division multiplexing. Similar to how phone lines can send different frequencies down the same cable to carry your voice and data transmissions, multiplexing allows significantly more throughput (bandwidth) to go down the same strand of fiber.

You mentioned that we will never be fully wireless, but I'd like to augment that statement. End users can and will have the ability to be fully wireless in the near future, but it will be because of the accelerated growth of fiber optic networks that will allow this to become a reality.

You would also be fascinated by some other optical fiber properties. Fibers by nature are much more difficult to tap into like you might with copper cable. As soon as you crack the fiber to attach in, the signal drops in strength and it's noticed on the receiving end. You can also run hundreds and thousands of fibers next to each other thanks to the cladding without the fear of mixed signals. If you try to do that with copper, you have a mess of magnetic fields to deal with (and you are also susceptible to external magnetic fields too!)

Many, but not all communication satellites are orbiting at 36,000 km, but some are much, much lower, as close as just a couple of hundred kms.

But the delay isn't in the distance traveled by the signal, but in the very complex and expensive electronics systems designed to send signals to and from orbit.

The electronics associated with terrestrial fibre optics is much, much simpler, cheaper, faster and more reliable than spacebourne satellite electronics.

And, as was briefly pointed out in the video, there is no rocket launch risk or expense associated with terrestrial fibre optics.

Neither the speed of light or signal distance traveled matter much at all. The big issue when comparing terrestrial fibre optics to satellites is the cost and speed of the electronics.

And the coolest part about optical fiber is that we make cables so well that we are still an order of magnitude away from maxing out the physical capabilities of our current fiber, so without having to redo the cabling, we can still make the internet a factor of 10 faster. After that we'll need to use a diamond/glass composite for diamond's wider bandwidth and a more acute critical angle, allowing for more physical space in multimode operation. Might be able to squeeze another order of magnitude out of that before we work out how to make fiber optics with a vacuum as a core...

Fibre optic is certainly the future communications infrastructure, it's just that communications companies (mainly in the western world...) have invested so heavily in their older copper networks, they're only really using fibre for backbone infrastructure. For most people this means FTTC (Fibre to the cabinet) installations at best, so a roadside cabinet is serviced by fibre and then distributed to homes using the existing copper network which works reasonably well as long as you don't truly live out in the sticks. The problem is that communications companies are spending lots of money to try to keep their copper networks somewhat relevant and charging customers more for the privilege (certainly in the US anyway, where fibre upgrades received government subsidies in the 90's but whilst the money was taken, the networks weren't upgraded...). On the other hand, fibre as a medium is far from being saturated and as a result, can be upgraded by changing the boxes at either end for faster equipment as newer technology develops, if only the communications companies would lay fibre lines to every home sooner rather than later so we can keep up with countries like South Korea!

as a network engineer: I think you missed one of the most intriguing features of fiber optics. it can carry different wavelengths of light (we call them channels) . sticking with your laser pointer analogy: it's possible to send the light of differently colored laser pointers through the water at the same time and sending a different morse code on each - color only is a difference in wavelength/frequency after all. if I got your attention you can take a look at the Wikipedia page covering this topic: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength-division_multiplexing there's even more science in there but the page is pretty OK
